Deep Hip Opening: Effectively stretches the hips and inner thighs, relieving hip tension from prolonged sitting.
Relieves Lower Back Discomfort: By relaxing the muscles around the hips, it indirectly reduces the burden on the lumbar spine and relieves back pain.
Improves Core Stability: Core engagement is required to hold the pose, which helps improve overall stability.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages the abdominal organs to promote digestion and elimination.
Relieves Knee and Ankle Pain: Helps relieve stiffness in the knees and ankles, enhancing joint flexibility.
description:
Start in Wide-Legged Child's Pose. Kneel on the floor with your feet together and your glutes on your heels.
Open your knees wide to the sides, forming a 'V' shape, and keep your feet together with your toes splayed outward. Slide your hands forward, bringing your chest and forehead to the ground.
Slowly lower your hips, trying to keep them in line with your knees. If it's difficult to lower your hips, you can keep them higher at first and gradually lower them with practice.
Keep your back straight and your core engaged, feeling the stretch in your inner thighs and hips. Breathe naturally. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more. Beginners can hold for 15-20 seconds and gradually increase to 30 seconds.
Slowly walk your hands back, lift your hips, and return to Wide-Legged Child's Pose.

name: Frog
benefits:
Stretches the Chest, Psoas, Quadriceps, and Ankles: Effectively stretches the front of the body, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Strengthens the Spine, Neck, Shoulders, Back, Diaphragm, Glutes, and Abdomen: The backbend action strengthens these areas.
Relieves Menstrual and Digestive Discomfort: Helps alleviate menstrual pain and indigestion.
Provides a Deep Hip Opening: Effectively stretches the hips and groin area.
description:
Start in a prone position on your mat, as if you were entering Bow Pose.
Bend both knees and bring your feet toward your glutes.
Press the soles of your feet down, bringing your heels toward your hips and splaying your toes outward.
Place your hands at your sides near your hips, palms facing down.
On an inhale, use the strength of your core and back to lift your chest and torso upward. Press down on the soles of your feet with your hands to help lift your upper body further.
If possible, rotate your hands so your fingers point forward and your elbows lift toward the ceiling. Roll your shoulder blades back to maintain a long back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine, hips, and inner thighs.
Slowly lower your chest, returning to a prone position and relaxing your entire body.

name: Garland Pose
benefits:
Stretches Ankles, Groin, and Back: Deeply stretches the leg and back muscles, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Strengthens Abdominal Muscles: Activates the abdominal core through the body's fold.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages the abdominal organs to promote digestion and metabolism.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching and breathing help relax the mind and body, relieving stress.
Enhances Hip Flexibility: Helps open the hip joints and increases hip flexibility.
description:
Start in a deep squat with your feet as close together as possible and your feet flat on the floor. If your heels don't reach the floor, place a folded yoga blanket or towel under them for support.
Open your knees slightly wider than your hips, turning your thighs out so your knees are as close to directly over your ankles as possible.
Lean your torso forward, tucking it between your thighs and keeping your back straight.
Place your hands on either side of your body, then bring your elbows inside your knees and your palms together in Anjali Mudra (prayer pose). Press your knees into your elbows to create a counter-force that helps lengthen the front of your torso.
Hold the pose, breathing deeply. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more. Hold for 5-10 breaths, feeling the stretch in your hips and legs.
Slowly release your hands, returning to a standing position or moving into the next pose.

name: Gate Pose
benefits:
Stretches Hips, Groin, and Shoulders: The side bend deeply stretches the hips and shoulders, relieving tension.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
Opens the Chest and Lungs: Helps expand the chest and increase lung capacity, improving breathing.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: Increases spinal flexibility through the side bend.
description:
Start in a kneeling position, with your legs together and your glutes resting on your heels.
On an exhale, straighten your right leg out to the side, flexing your foot so your right leg is fully extended.
On an inhale, extend your arms out to your sides, parallel to the floor, with your palms facing down.
On an exhale, bend to the side, reaching your left arm over your head toward your right leg. You can rest your right hand on your right leg to help stabilize your body.
Hold the pose with steady breaths, feeling the stretch along the side of your body, especially on your left side. Hold for 3-5 breaths, lengthening your body with each inhale and deepening the stretch with each exhale.
On an inhale, bring your left arm back overhead and return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Gheranda's
benefits:
Stretches the Front of the Body: Deeply stretches the ankles, thighs, groin, abdomen, chest, and throat.
Strengthens Back Muscles: Builds strength in the spine and back.
Enhances Flexibility: Increases flexibility in the hips and spine.
Promotes Digestion: Stimulates abdominal organs to relieve indigestion.
description:
Start in a prone position on your mat, preparing for Bow Pose.
Rotate your hands so your knuckles face forward and your elbows point toward the ceiling.
Bend your knee on the same side (e.g., your right knee), trying to bring your knee and the sole of your foot as close to the floor as possible.
Straighten your other leg (e.g., your left leg) and lift it upward.
Lift your chest and look up.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more.
Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

name: Goddess
benefits:
Strengthens Glutes, Hips, Thighs, Calves, and Ankles: Builds lower body strength through the squat and leg support.
Opens the Hips and Chest: Deeply stretches the hips, increasing hip joint flexibility, while opening the chest and improving breathing.
Stretches the Thighs and Lengthens the Spine: The squat and spinal extension relieve tension in the legs and back.
Improves Core Stability: Activates the abdominal core to enhance overall stability.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help relax the mind and body.
description:
Start in Mountain Pose with your feet together and your hands at your sides.
Step your feet out to the sides, as wide as your mat, or slightly wider than your hips. Turn your toes outward, pointing toward the two corners of the mat, and your heels inward.
Bend your knees, keeping them aligned with your toes and not going past your toes. Slowly lower your hips into a deep squat.
Gently tuck your tailbone and press your hips forward while pulling your thighs back, creating a 'tucking in' sensation. Engage your lower abdomen and lift your ribs, keeping your spine long.
Keep your knees aligned with your toes, avoiding any inward or outward rolling of the knees. Relax your shoulders, keeping them down and away from your ears. Breathe steadily. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lift your body and return to Mountain Pose.

name: Gorilla
benefits:
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and relaxation help calm the mind.
Stimulates the Liver and Kidneys: Improves blood circulation to internal organs.
Stretches the Hamstrings and Calves: Enhances leg flexibility.
Strengthens Thigh Muscles: Builds thigh strength by keeping the legs straight.
Improves Digestive Function: Promotes intestinal peristalsis and relieves indigestion.
Relieves Headaches and Fatigue: Relaxes the neck and shoulders, relieving tension.
description:
Start in Mountain Pose with your feet parallel and about 6 inches (15 cm) apart. Engage your quadriceps and lift your kneecaps.
Fold forward from your hips, keeping your legs completely straight and your upper body parallel to the floor.
Slide your index and middle fingers between your big and second toes. Wrap your fingers and thumb around your toes. Press your toes down to create a counter-pull against your fingers.
Lift your sitting bones up and lengthen them toward the ceiling. Bring your upper body closer to your thighs, letting the crown of your head hang down. Depending on your flexibility, you can have a slight arch in your lower back, but avoid over-compressing it. Keep your chest lifted to avoid pressure on the back of your neck. Relax your forehead. To lengthen the front of your body, you can bend your elbows out to the sides, pulling up on your toes.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly release your hands and return to a standing position, relaxing your entire body.

name: Half Frog
benefits:
Stretches the Chest, Psoas, Quadriceps, and Ankles: Half Frog Pose effectively relieves tension in these areas.
Strengthens Core Muscles: Activates the abdominal core by holding the pose.
Enhances Hip Flexibility: Deeply stretches the hips, which helps improve overall flexibility.
Relieves Menstrual and Digestive Discomfort: Helps alleviate menstrual pain and indigestion.
description:
Start by lying on your stomach with your legs together and your hands at your sides.
Shift your weight to one side (e.g., the right side) and support yourself on your right forearm to lift your upper body.
Use your left hand to reach back and grab your right foot. Bend your right knee and pull your heel toward your glute. If possible, bring your right foot to the inside of your right thigh, with the top of your foot on the ground.
Point your right hand forward and lift your right elbow toward the ceiling. Your left hand should point backward, with your left elbow pressing toward the ground. Keep your shoulder blades pressed back to open your chest.
Press your pubic bone down to lengthen your psoas and quadriceps. Hold the pose with steady breaths, lengthening your spine with each inhale and relaxing your hips a bit more with each exhale. Hold for 10-15 breaths.
Slowly release your right foot and return to a prone position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Half Moon
benefits:
Strengthens the Abdomen, Ankles, Thighs, Glutes, and Spine: Builds strength in the lower body and core through single-leg support.
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, Calves, Shoulders, Chest, and Spine: Deeply stretches multiple parts of the body, improving flexibility.
Improves Coordination and Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance, which helps enhance body coordination.
Relieves Stress: Deep breathing and balance practice help relieve stress and improve mental well-being.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
description:
Start in Mountain Pose with your feet together and your hands at your sides.
Enter Triangle Pose by stepping your feet apart, slightly wider than shoulder-width. Turn your right foot out 90 degrees and your left foot in about 15 degrees. Bend your right knee and place your right hand on the floor outside your right foot, with your left arm extended upward.
Shift your weight onto your right leg. Bend your right knee, lift your left leg back, and simultaneously lean your upper body to the left, with your left arm reaching toward the ceiling.
Straighten your right leg and press your right foot firmly into the ground. Continue to extend your left leg back, parallel to the ground (or slightly above). Place your right hand on the floor about 30 cm (12 inches) outside your right foot. Continue to extend your left arm upward, forming a straight line with your body.
Engage your abdominal core to stabilize your body. Ensure your right leg is straight, your left leg is parallel to the ground, and your left arm is perpendicular to the ground. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and extend your fingers outward, creating a counter-force. Lift the inner arch of your right foot as if drawing energy from the ground. Press your sacrum and shoulder blades back, lengthening your tailbone toward your lifted left foot. Depending on your neck's comfort, you can look up or down. If you have a neck injury, look down.
Slowly lower your left leg, return to Triangle Pose, and then to Mountain Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: Revolved Half Moon
benefits:
Strengthens the Abdomen, Ankles, Thighs, Glutes, and Spine.
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, Calves, Shoulders, Chest, and Spine.
Improves Coordination and Balance.
Relieves Stress and improves digestive function.
Opens the Shoulders, Hips, and Pelvis.
Enhances flexibility and stretching along the side of the body.
description:
Start in Half Moon Pose with your right leg supporting your weight and your left leg lifted back, parallel to the ground.
Slowly lower your top hand (your left arm) to the floor, placing it where your bottom hand (your right arm) was. On an inhale, extend your right arm upward, toward the ceiling.
Twist your pelvis to the left, stacking your shoulders so your left shoulder is directly above your right shoulder. Keep your spine long, and your left arm up and your right arm down, forming a straight line.
Engage your abdominal core to stabilize your body. Look up toward your left fingertips. If you feel unstable, you can look down at the floor.
Slowly lower your left leg, return to Triangle Pose, and then to Mountain Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: Handstand
benefits:
Strengthens Shoulders, Arms, and Wrists: Builds upper body and shoulder strength by supporting your body weight with your arms.
Stretches the Abdomen: The inversion effectively stretches the abdominal area.
Improves Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance, which helps enhance body coordination.
Relieves Stress: The inversion promotes blood circulation, which helps calm the mind and relieve stress.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog. Place your hands on the floor shoulder-width apart, with your fingers pointing forward and parallel. If your shoulders are tight, you can slightly rotate your index fingers outward.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together and lift them toward your tailbone. Rotate your upper arms outward so the insides of your elbows face forward. Keep your shoulder blades wide while hugging your outer arms in, creating a counter-force to maintain balance and stability.
Spread your palms wide and press firmly into the base of your fingers (especially the base of your index finger) for stable support.
Slowly walk one foot (e.g., your right foot) toward your hands, bending your knee and bringing it close to your chest. Use your core and arm strength to lift your right foot, then lift your other foot (your left foot). Bring your legs together and your body perpendicular to the floor.
Engage your core muscles. Push your body away from the floor with your straight arms. Flex your feet and straighten your legs. Breathe steadily, lengthening your spine with each inhale and stabilizing your body with each exhale.
Slowly lower one foot at a time, returning to Downward-Facing Dog, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Scorpion Handstand
benefits:
Stretches the Front of the Body: Deeply stretches the chest, neck, spine, and abdomen.
Strengthens Upper Body: Builds strength in the arms, shoulders, and back.
Promotes Blood Circulation: Inversion promotes blood flow to the head, improving brain circulation.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog. Place your forearms on the floor, shoulder-width apart.
Keep your shoulders directly over your elbows and try to kick one leg up to enter Handstand. Ensure your arms are straight, your shoulders are away from your ears, and your core is engaged.
Once in Handstand, slowly bend your knees and move your hips back, past your shoulders. Push your chest forward and arch your spine into a gentle backbend.
Slowly bring your feet toward your head, trying to touch your head with your toes. Maintain stability in your arms and core, and avoid swaying.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breathing and maintaining balance. You can look at the floor or forward, adjusting your gaze based on your balance.
Slowly lower your feet back to Handstand. Then exit Handstand and return to Downward-Facing Dog or Mountain Pose.

name: One Legged Scorpion Handstand
benefits:
Stretches and Strengthens: Stretches the chest, neck, spine, and abdomen while strengthening the arms, shoulders, and back.
Improves Balance: Develops body balance and focus.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inversion promotes blood flow to the head, improving brain circulation.
description:
Start in Handstand with your hands shoulder-width apart, your arms straight, and your shoulders directly over your wrists.
Keep your arms stable and look forward, slightly tucking your head. Arch your back and move your hips behind your shoulders. Bend your knees and bring your toes toward your head to enter Scorpion Pose.
With control, lift one leg (e.g., your left leg) upward and straighten it, engaging your leg muscles and flexing your foot. Your right leg remains bent, with your toes as close to your head as possible.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breathing and feeling the balance and strength in your body. Gaze toward the ceiling to maintain your balance.
Slowly bring your lifted leg back to its original position, returning to Scorpion Pose. Then lower both legs, returning to Handstand before exiting the pose.

name: Supported Headstand
benefits:
Strengthens the Shoulders, Arms, and Spine.
Stretches the Abdomen.
Improves Balance.
Relieves Stress and Mild Depression.
Stimulates the Pituitary and Pineal Glands.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog. Interlace your hands and place your forearms on the floor, with your elbows shoulder-width apart. Gently place the crown of your head on the floor between your hands, with most of your weight supported by your forearms.
Squeeze your shoulder blades back and down, lifting your upper back. Lift your tailbone up, keeping your spine long. Press firmly into the base of your fingers (especially the index fingers) for stable support.
Slowly walk one foot (e.g., your right foot) toward your hands, bending your knee and bringing it close to your chest. Use your core and arm strength to lift your right foot, then lift your other foot (your left foot). Bring your legs together and your body perpendicular to the floor.
Keep your core engaged. Push your body away from the floor with your straight arms. Flex your feet and straighten your legs. Breathe steadily, lengthening your spine with each inhale and stabilizing your body with each exhale.
Slowly lower one foot at a time, returning to Downward-Facing Dog.

name: Supported Headstand Pike
benefits:
Strengthens: Builds strength in the arms, legs, and core.
Improves Balance: Develops body balance and coordination.
Enhances Blood Circulation: Promotes blood flow to the head, improving brain circulation.
description:
Start in a kneeling position with your glutes on your heels and your hands at your sides.
Create a base: Place your elbows on the mat, shoulder-width apart. Clasp your hands together, forming a stable triangular frame. Gently place the crown of your head inside your clasped hands, ensuring the pressure is on the crown, not your forehead.
Lift your hips, forming an inverted 'V' shape, similar to Downward-Facing Dog. Slowly walk your feet toward your head until your heels lift off the ground.
Keep your legs together and engage your core. Slowly lower your legs to form an 'L' shape. Keep your spine long and avoid arching your lower back.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breathing and maintaining your balance.
Slowly lower your legs back to the floor and return to a kneeling position.

name: One Legged Supported Headstand
benefits:
Promotes Blood Circulation: Inversion promotes blood flow to the head, improving brain circulation.
Strengthens: Builds strength in the arms, legs, and core, enhancing overall body stability.
Improves Balance: The challenge of single-leg balance enhances body coordination and balance.
Relieves Stress: Inversion helps relax the mind and body, relieving stress and anxiety.
description:
Start in the preparation for Supported Headstand. Place your elbows on the ground, shoulder-width apart, and interlace your hands, forming a stable triangular frame. Gently place the crown of your head inside your clasped hands, ensuring the pressure is on the crown, not your forehead.
On an inhale, lift your hips into an inverted 'V' shape, similar to Downward-Facing Dog. Slowly walk your feet toward your head until your heels lift off the ground.
Ensure your forearms are pressed evenly into the ground and your body weight is on your head and forearms. Slowly bring one foot (e.g., your right foot) toward your head while lifting the other leg (your left leg) upward, as straight as possible.
Engage your core to stabilize your body. Your left leg should be straight, and your right leg remains bent with your heel close to your glute. Keep your spine long and avoid arching your lower back. Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breathing and feeling the balance in your body.
Slowly lower your left leg back to the floor, returning to the preparation for Supported Headstand. Repeat on the other side.

name: Tripod Headstand
benefits:
Strengthens Shoulders, Arms, and Spine.
Stretches the Abdomen.
Improves Balance.
Relieves Stress and Mild Depression.
Stimulates the Pituitary and Pineal Glands.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog. Place your hands on the mat shoulder-width apart, with your fingers spread and palms facing down.
Bend your elbows so they point backward, and lean your body forward. Gently place the crown of your head on the ground, forming an equilateral triangle with your head and hands.
Slowly walk your feet toward your hands until your hips are directly over your shoulders.
Use your core strength to lift one leg (e.g., your right leg), then lift the other leg (your left leg). Bring your legs together and your body perpendicular to the floor. Keep your legs straight and your feet flexed to engage your leg muscles.
Breathe steadily. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body. Ensure your head and hands are evenly supporting your body weight, and avoid pressure on your neck.
Slowly lower one leg (e.g., your right leg), then the other (your left leg), returning to Downward-Facing Dog.

name: Head to Knee I
benefits:
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, and Shoulders: Deeply stretches the inner thighs, hamstrings, and shoulders, relieving tension.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The forward bend increases spinal length and flexibility.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
Relieves Sciatica: Stretches the hamstrings, reducing pressure on the sciatic nerve.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and place the sole of your right foot on your inner left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible. Rotate your right knee outward and upward, ensuring your right leg is comfortably resting on the floor.
Keep your left leg straight and press your knee down toward the floor, ensuring your leg is fully extended. Your right leg should form an angle with your left leg.
Align your chest and abdomen with your straight left leg. Lengthen your spine and reach your arms up, feeling the extension in your spine.
Slowly fold your body forward, bringing your abdomen toward your left leg while keeping your spine long. Engage your abdomen, pulling your navel toward your spine to maintain spinal length.
Depending on your flexibility, you can hold onto your left ankle, foot, or toes with both hands. You can also wrap your hands around your left foot and grab your wrist to create a bind. Or, you can place your hands on either side of your left leg for balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and hamstrings a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lift your torso and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Head to Knee II
benefits:
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, and Shoulders: Deeply stretches the inner thighs, hamstrings, and shoulders, relieving tension.
Activates the Pelvic Floor: The pressure of the heel on the perineum helps activate the pelvic floor muscles.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The forward bend increases spinal length and flexibility.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and place the sole of your right foot on your inner left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible.
Keep your left leg straight and press your knee down toward the floor, ensuring your leg is fully extended. Your right leg should form an angle with your left leg.
Place your hands on the floor at your sides, slightly in front of you. On an inhale, lift your hips and place your perineum on your right heel. If you have good flexibility, you can keep your foot flexed.
Slowly fold your body forward, bringing your abdomen toward your left leg while keeping your spine long. Engage your abdomen, pulling your navel toward your spine to maintain spinal length.
Depending on your flexibility, you can hold onto your left ankle, foot, or toes with both hands. You can also wrap your hands around your left foot and grab your wrist to create a bind. Or, you can place your hands on either side of your left leg for balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and hamstrings a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lift your torso and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Head to Knee III
benefits:
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, Achilles Tendon, and Shoulders: Deeply stretches the inner thighs, hamstrings, Achilles tendon, and shoulders, relieving tension.
Activates the Pelvic Floor: The pressure of the heel on the perineum helps activate the pelvic floor muscles.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The forward bend increases spinal length and flexibility.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and place the sole of your right foot on your inner left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible.
Keep your left leg straight and press your knee down toward the floor, ensuring your leg is fully extended. Your right leg should form an angle with your left leg.
Externally rotate your right hip and place the outer edge of your right foot on the floor, with your heel as close to your inner left thigh as possible.
Place your hands on the floor at your sides, slightly in front of you. On an inhale, lift your hips and place the top of your right foot on the top of your left foot.
Slowly fold your body forward, bringing your abdomen toward your left leg while keeping your spine long. Engage your abdomen, pulling your navel toward your spine to maintain spinal length.
Depending on your flexibility, you can hold onto your left ankle, foot, or toes with both hands. You can also wrap your hands around your left foot and grab your wrist to create a bind. Or, you can place your hands on either side of your left leg for balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and hamstrings a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lift your torso and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Revolved Head to Knee
benefits:
Stretches the Spine and Hamstrings: Deeply stretches the spine, shoulders, side body, and hamstrings, improving body flexibility.
Enhances Balance: The twisting and side-bending motion develops body balance and coordination.
Relieves Stress: Twisting stimulates abdominal organs, relieving stress and anxiety.
Improves Digestion: Promotes blood circulation to abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs as wide as possible and your spine straight.
Bend your right knee, bringing your right heel close to your left groin. The sole of your right foot should face upward, and your right knee should open outward. Keep your left leg straight, and your heel extended forward as much as possible.
On an inhale, extend your arms upward in line with your ears. On an exhale, bend your body to the side toward your left leg, trying to place your right hand on the inside of your left knee while your left arm extends upward.
Twist your body, keeping your left leg straight and your right knee stable. Start the twist from your abdomen, lifting your left arm upward. Lean back and wrap your left arm behind your ear, grabbing the outside of your left foot.
Spread your elbows out and use the strength of your arms to deepen the twist. Turn your head to look up at the ceiling. Keep your spine long and avoid collapsing or arching your back.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and twist in your spine.
On an inhale, slowly bring your left arm back to your side and your body back to the center. Repeat on the other side.

name: Hero
benefits:
Stretches the Thighs, Knees, and Ankles: Deeply stretches the inner thighs, knees, and ankles, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Strengthens the Foot Arches: The ankle stretch strengthens the foot arches.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs, relieving bloating and promoting digestion.
Relieves Menstrual Discomfort: Helps alleviate menstrual pain and discomfort.
description:
Start in a kneeling position, with your knees on the floor and your feet together, and your glutes resting on your heels. If your knees, calves, or feet feel uncomfortable, place a folded yoga blanket under your knees for support.
Shift your body weight so you are sitting between your feet on the floor. If you can't comfortably sit on the floor, place a yoga block between your feet to raise your glutes.
Ensure there's about a thumb's width of space between the inside of your feet and the outside of your hips. Internally rotate your thighs, and press your thigh bones down toward the floor.
Place your hands on your thighs or knees, with your palms facing down, and relax your shoulders. Or, place your hands on your thighs with your palms facing up to feel more relaxed.
Squeeze your shoulder blades back and together, lifting your breastbone as if you were a proud warrior. Broaden your collarbones and move your shoulder blades away from your ears to avoid shrugging. Lengthen your tailbone down to anchor your back and keep your spine long.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and thighs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the relaxation and stretch in your body.
Slowly lift your body, return to a kneeling position, and relax your entire body.

name: Heron
benefits:
Stretches the Thighs, Knees, and Ankles: Effectively relieves tension in the leg muscles.
Strengthens the Core: Activates the abdominal core by holding your balance.
Improves Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs to relieve bloating.
Enhances Flexibility: Increases flexibility in the legs and hips.
description:
Start by sitting on the floor with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and move your right foot backward, placing it next to your right hip. Your toes should point backward and the top of your foot should be on the floor. The inside of your right calf should be close to the outside of your right thigh. Ensure your right knee is as close to the other as possible to maintain stability.
Bend your left knee and use both hands to hug your left foot. Lift your left leg straight up, keeping your back straight.
Hold the pose for a few breaths, feeling the stretch in your hamstrings. Keep your spine long, your chest open, and your breastbone lifted.
Slowly lower your left leg, release your hands, straighten your right leg, and return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Supine Hero
benefits:
Stretches the Abdomen, Thighs, and Deep Hip Flexors (Psoas): Deeply stretches the abdomen and inner thighs, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Relieves Leg Fatigue: Relaxes the leg muscles, relieving fatigue and soreness.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs to promote digestion.
Relieves Menstrual Discomfort: Helps alleviate menstrual pain and discomfort.
Strengthens the Foot Arches: The ankle stretch strengthens the foot arches.
description:
Start by lying on your back on the mat with your legs straight.
Bend your knees and bring your feet to the sides of your body, with your feet flat on the floor and hip-width apart. Keep your legs parallel, and press your thigh bones down, deep into the hip sockets.
If your hips feel tight, you can slightly lift your knees off the floor to relieve pressure. You can also place a folded yoga blanket under your knees for support to prevent tension in your hips and lower back.
Place your arms at your sides, palms facing up, and relax your shoulders away from your ears.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and abdomen a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the relaxation and stretch in your body.
Slowly straighten your legs and return to a supine position, or move into Child's Pose for relaxation.

name: Horse
benefits:
Improves Posture and Balance: Enhances body coordination and balance through single-leg support and arm coordination.
Increases Flexibility in Shoulders, Hips, Knees, and Ankles: Deeply stretches and rotates joints, improving overall flexibility.
Strengthens Abdominal Muscles: Activates the abdominal core by maintaining balance.
description:
Start in Standing Half Lotus Pose, with your feet hip-width apart.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot into a lotus position on your left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible. Externally rotate your left foot, pointing your toes forward, and slightly bend your left knee.
On an inhale, lean your upper body forward and gently place your right knee on the floor. Externally rotate your left foot, placing your heel directly in front of your right knee, and keep your left leg rotated outward for stability.
Lift your chest and look forward, maintaining your balance. Bring your arms into Eagle Pose, with the top arm corresponding to the leg in lotus position (your right leg).
Tuck your tailbone and lift your chest forward and up, keeping your spine long. Keep your Eagle arms lifted and away from your chest to help with balance. Hold the pose with steady breaths, lengthening your spine with each inhale and stabilizing your body with each exhale. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lift your right knee and return to Standing Half Lotus Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: Shoelace Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Ankles, Hips, and Thighs: Effectively relieves tension in the leg muscles.
Relaxes the Sacrum: Reduces back pressure and relieves lower back pain.
Improves Urinary System Function: Provides excellent benefits for both the urinary and digestive systems.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and tuck your right foot under your left leg, placing it on the outside of your left hip. Then bend your left knee and place your left foot on the outside of your right hip, trying to stack your knees on top of each other.
Place your hands at your sides. On an inhale, lift your torso and lengthen your spine. On an exhale, fold your body forward. You can place your hands at your sides or hold onto your ankles to help with stability.
Keep your spine long and your chest open. Press your tailbone down to avoid arching your back. Hold the pose for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch in your hips and inner thighs.
On an inhale, use your hands or abdominal muscles to lift your spine from your tailbone. Straighten your legs and use your hands for support behind you. Slowly release your hands and legs, and then get up from the side to repeat on the other side.

name: Little Thunderbolt
benefits:
Stretches the Front of the Body: Includes the ankles, thighs, hips, abdomen, chest, and throat.
Strengthens Back Muscles: Builds back strength.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs, relieving constipation and bloating.
Enhances Respiratory Function: Increases oxygen flow, improving the respiratory system.
Relieves Stress: As a restorative pose, it helps reduce stress and anxiety.
description:
Start in Camel Pose, holding your ankles, calves, or the front of your thighs with your hands.
Slowly shift your body weight forward. Bend your right leg, tucking your right foot under your left leg and placing it on the outside of your left hip. Then bend your left leg, placing your left foot on the outside of your right hip, trying to stack your knees.
Place your hands at your sides. On an inhale, lift your torso and lengthen your spine. On an exhale, fold your body forward. You can place your hands at your sides or hold onto your ankles to help with stability.
From Thunderbolt Pose, lean back and bend your elbows, using your arms for support as you lower yourself. Slowly place your head and upper body on the floor, keeping your knees close together and your feet and ankles touching.
Once you are lying down, you can extend your arms overhead, then bring them back to hold your feet (ankles), or place them by your sides or on your thighs. Keep your spine long and your chest open. Hold for 3-5 minutes.
To exit the pose, reverse the movement, using your arms to lift your head, then your upper body, and return to the starting position.

name: Lizard
benefits:
Enhances Hip Flexibility: Deeply stretches the hip flexors, hamstrings, and inner thighs, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Strengthens Leg Muscles: Builds strength in the quadriceps and glutes.
Improves Posture: Stretching and strengthening these muscles can improve pelvic alignment and overall posture.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help reduce mental stress.
description:
Start in Plank Pose or Downward-Facing Dog. Step one foot (e.g., your right foot) forward to the outer edge of the same-side hand, with both hands on the inside of your front leg.
Keep your front knee (right knee) directly over your ankle, avoiding it going past your toes. Keep your back heel (left heel) lifted and your toes on the ground, extending back. Engage your quadriceps and lift your kneecap.
Distribute your body weight evenly between your hips, keeping your hips level. If it's comfortable, you can lower your body weight and extend your arms forward, placing them on the floor on either side of your front leg.
Keep your spine long and your chest open, and slightly lift your chin. Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your hips and inner thighs.
Slowly lift your body weight and return to Plank Pose or Downward-Facing Dog. Repeat on the other side.

name: Locust I
benefits:
Strengthens the Spine, Glutes, and Back of the Legs.
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, Abdomen, and Thighs.
Corrects Rounded Shoulders and Hunchback: Lengthens the spine to correct poor posture.
Relieves Lumbar Disc Herniation: Stretches the spine and reduces pressure on the lower back.
Promotes Digestion: Massages abdominal organs to relieve bloating.
description:
Start by lying on your stomach on your mat, with your body in a straight line, your feet hip-width apart, and the tops of your feet on the floor. Place your hands at your sides with your palms facing up.
On an exhale, contract your glutes and slowly lift your legs, chest, and head off the floor. Keep your legs together, engaging the middle of your thighs to lift them up and back, with your toes extending backward.
On an inhale, lift your head and chest. Look forward or up, lengthening your spine. Extend your arms backward, with your palms facing up and parallel to the floor.
Keep your spine long in both directions, avoiding any compression in the lower back. Engage your core to keep your body stable. Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths.
On an exhale, slowly lower your head, chest, and legs back to the prone position.

name: Locust II
benefits:
Strengthens the Spine, Glutes, and Back of the Legs.
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, Abdomen, and Thighs.
Corrects Rounded Shoulders and Hunchback: Lengthens the spine to correct poor posture.
Relieves Lumbar Disc Herniation: Stretches the spine and reduces pressure on the lower back.
Promotes Digestion: Massages abdominal organs to relieve bloating.
description:
Start by lying on your stomach on your mat, with your body in a straight line, your feet hip-width apart, and the tops of your feet on the floor.
Bend your elbows and place your hands at your sides with your palms facing down. Your fingers should point forward, and your elbows should be tucked in close to your body.
On an inhale, use the strength of your hands to press into the floor, lifting your chest and head off the floor. At the same time, lift your legs up, keeping them straight and your toes extending backward. Keep your spine long, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Lengthen your entire body in both directions, avoiding bending your knees. Engage your core to keep your body stable. Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, feeling the strength in your spine and legs.
On an exhale, slowly lower your head, chest, and legs back to the prone position.

name: Locust III
benefits:
Strengthens the Spine, Glutes, and Back of the Legs.
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, Abdomen, and Thighs.
Corrects Rounded Shoulders and Hunchback: Lengthens the spine to correct poor posture.
Relieves Lumbar Disc Herniation: Stretches the spine and reduces pressure on the lower back.
Promotes Digestion: Massages abdominal organs to relieve bloating.
description:
Start by lying on your stomach on your mat with your legs together and the tops of your feet on the floor. Extend your arms forward, parallel to your body, with your palms facing down, similar to 'Reversed Corpse Pose.'
On an inhale, simultaneously lift your chest and thighs off the floor. Keep your legs straight, with your toes extending backward. Extend your hands forward, feeling the length in your spine.
Keep your thighs and big toes as close together as possible, keeping your legs straight. Keep your neck long and look slightly forward, avoiding over-arching.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the strength in your spine and legs.
On an exhale, slowly lower your chest and legs back to the prone position.

name: Lord of the Fishes
benefits:
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The twisting motion increases the flexibility and elasticity of the spine.
Stretches and Strengthens: Effectively stretches and strengthens the spine, shoulders, and hips.
Relieves Fatigue and Stress: This pose can relax the body and reduce fatigue and stress.
description:
Start in Half Lotus Pose, with your right foot on your left thigh.
Bend your left knee and bring it toward your chest. Twist your body to the left. Wrap your left arm around your body and firmly grasp your right ankle with your left hand.
Move your right shoulder over your left knee and then grab your left foot with your right hand. Keep your spine long and avoid over-arching your lower back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, deepen the twist. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine and hips.
Slowly release your hands, return to Half Lotus Pose, and repeat on the other side.

name: Half Lord of the Fishes
benefits:
Stretches the Spine: Effectively relieves back tension and enhances spinal flexibility.
Relieves Shoulder Stiffness: The twisting motion relaxes the shoulder and neck muscles.
Promotes Digestion: Stimulates abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
Relieves Fatigue: Helps relax the mind and body, relieving stress.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the outside of your left thigh, with your right heel close to your left hip. Bend your left knee and place your left foot on the inside of your right thigh, with the sole of your left foot flat on the floor.
On an inhale, lengthen your spine and place your hands at your sides. On an exhale, extend your right arm upward and twist to the left, placing your right elbow against the outside of your left knee.
Place your left hand behind you, with your fingertips pointing back, to help stabilize your body. Continue to twist to the left with your right hand, grabbing your left knee or left foot to deepen the twist.
Keep your spine long, avoiding slouching or arching your back. With each inhale, feel the length in your spine; with each exhale, deepen the twist. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, focusing on your deep breaths.
On an inhale, slowly return your body to center, bringing your right arm back to your side. Straighten your legs and repeat on the other side.

name: Scale Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Wrists, Arms, and Abdomen: The arm and abdominal support builds strength in the upper body and core.
Improves Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance, which helps enhance body coordination.
Relieves Stiffness from Prolonged Sitting: The lotus posture relieves tension in the hips and legs.
description:
Start in Full Lotus Pose, with your legs crossed and your feet on top of the opposite thighs. Place your hands on the floor at your sides.
Place your hands on the floor at your sides, hip-width apart, with your fingers spread and palms facing down.
On an inhale, use the strength of your hands to press into the floor while contracting your abdominal muscles. Lift your legs and glutes off the floor. Keep your spine long and avoid over-arching your lower back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the strength in your wrists, arms, and abdomen.
On an exhale, slowly lower your legs and glutes back to the floor, returning to Full Lotus Pose.

name: Lotus Pose
benefits:
Opens the Hips and Groin: Deeply stretches the hips and groin, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Stretches the Knees, Ankles, and Thighs: Enhances flexibility in the legs.
Strengthens the Back: The straight spine strengthens the back muscles.
Calms the Mind, Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Suitable for meditation and relaxation, helping to reduce mental stress.
Improves Pelvic Blood Circulation: Promotes blood circulation in the pelvic area, relieving menstrual discomfort.
description:
Start in Half Lotus Pose, with your legs crossed. Place your right foot on your left thigh and your left foot on your right thigh.
The sole of your right foot should face up, and it should be as close to your left groin as possible. The sole of your left foot should face up, and it should be as close to your right groin as possible. Ensure your feet are stable and avoid excessive bending or pressure on your knees.
Place your hands on your knees with your palms facing up to enter the basic Lotus Pose. Keep your spine straight and your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch in your hips and thighs.
Slowly straighten your legs, return to a seated position, and relax your entire body.

name: Runners Lunge Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Lower Body: Builds strength in the thighs, calves, and ankles.
Improves Body Stability: Single-leg support enhances balance and coordination.
Stretches the Hips and Groin: Deeply stretches the hips and groin, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Promotes Flexibility: Increases flexibility in the front and back of the body.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
description:
Start in Mountain Pose or Downward-Facing Dog.
Step your right foot forward between your hands. Bend your right knee to a 90-degree angle, keeping it directly over your right ankle. Extend your left leg back, with your heel lifted and your toes on the floor, keeping your leg straight.
Push your hips forward, keeping them squared to the front and avoiding any twisting. Squeeze your inner thighs together to keep your hips stable. Tuck your tailbone down to protect your lower back and lift your chest to open your heart.
Place your hands on the floor on either side of your right leg, with your fingers spread and your palms facing down, to help with balance. If needed, you can place yoga blocks under your hands to maintain proper alignment.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and thighs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your body.
On an exhale, step your right foot back to Downward-Facing Dog. Repeat on the other side.

name: Crescent Lunge
benefits:
Strengthens the Lower Body: Builds strength in the thighs, calves, and ankles.
Improves Balance: Single-leg support enhances balance and coordination.
Stretches the Hips and Groin: Deeply stretches the hips and groin, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Promotes Flexibility: Increases flexibility in the front and back of the body.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog.
Step your right foot forward between your hands. Bend your right knee to a 90-degree angle, keeping it directly over your right ankle. Straighten your left leg, lifting your heel and keeping your toes on the floor. Shift your weight backward onto your toes while pressing your left heel down and back.
Push your hips forward, keeping them squared to the front and avoiding any twisting. Squeeze your inner thighs together, and tuck your tailbone down to protect your lower back. Lift your chest and lengthen your spine, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Extend your arms upward, perpendicular to the floor, with your palms facing each other or in Anjali Mudra (prayer pose). Spread your fingers, and squeeze your shoulder blades back and down to lift your upper back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and thighs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your body.
On an exhale, step your right foot back to Downward-Facing Dog. Repeat on the other side.

name: Low Lunge Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Chest, Lungs, Neck, Abdomen, and Groin: Deeply stretches the front of the body, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Strengthens the Shoulders, Arms, and Back: The arm extension builds strength in the upper body and back muscles.
Strengthens and Stretches the Thighs, Calves, and Ankles: The low lunge posture builds leg strength and improves flexibility.
Enhances Respiratory Function: Opens the chest, increasing lung capacity and improving breathing.
Relieves Stress and Anxiety: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog, with your feet hip-width apart and your hands on the floor, forming an inverted 'V' shape with your body.
On an inhale, step your right foot forward between your hands. Bend your right knee to a 90-degree angle, keeping it directly over your right ankle. Place your left knee on the floor, with the top of your left foot on the floor and your toes flexed to engage your calf muscles.
Push your hips forward, keeping them squared to the front and avoiding any twisting. Squeeze your inner thighs together, and tuck your tailbone down to protect your lower back. Lift your chest and lengthen your spine, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Extend your arms upward, perpendicular to the floor, with your palms facing each other or in Anjali Mudra (prayer pose). Spread your fingers, and squeeze your shoulder blades back and down to lift your upper back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and thighs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your body.
On an exhale, step your right foot back to Downward-Facing Dog. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Koundinya B
benefits:
Strengthens Arms, Legs, and Core: The weight-bearing support builds strength in the upper body, legs, and core.
Improves Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance, which helps enhance body coordination.
Stretches the Hips and Hamstrings: Deeply stretches the hips and leg muscles, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Promotes Flexibility: Increases flexibility in the front and back of the body.
description:
Start in Runner's Lunge, with your right foot forward and your left leg straight back, with your toes on the floor.
Place your hands on the floor on the inside of your right leg, with your palms facing down and your fingers spread, pressing into the floor.
Bend your elbows to a 90-degree angle, keeping your right knee directly over your ankle at a 90-degree angle. Place your right leg on top of your right elbow, with your right foot gently resting on your left arm.
Keep your left leg straight back, with your toes flexed to engage your leg muscles and maintain balance. Your body should be parallel to the floor. Lengthen your spine, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your body.
Slowly lower your right leg back to Lunge, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Revolved Crescent Lunge on the Knee
benefits:
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The twisting motion stretches the spine and increases its flexibility.
Improves Rib Cage Flexibility: Helps relax the rib cage area, improving breathing efficiency.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Massages abdominal organs, promoting digestion and relieving constipation.
Improves Balance: Develops body balance and coordination.
Relieves Stress: Twisting and deep breathing help relieve stress and anxiety.
description:
Start in Low Lunge, with your right knee forward, your left knee on the floor, and your hands on your right knee, keeping your spine long.
On an inhale, place your hands on the outside of your right knee, with your right elbow gently pressing against the outside of your right knee. Keep your right knee stable. On an exhale, slowly twist your body to the right, stacking your left shoulder over your right shoulder.
Your right hand can be on your right knee, and your left hand can point toward the ceiling. Alternatively, you can have your palms together, with your left elbow pressing against the outside of your right knee. Keep your spine long and your chest open. Gaze toward your left fingertips or the ceiling. Engage your core to stabilize your body.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, feeling the twist in your spine and the stretch in your rib cage. Focus on your breath and direct your attention to the twist and stretch.
On an inhale, slowly return your body to the center and bring your hands back to your sides. Repeat on the other side.

name: Seated Spinal Twist
benefits:
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The twisting motion effectively improves the flexibility of the spine.
Stretches the Shoulders and Back: Twisting stretches the shoulders and back, relieving stiffness.
Massages Abdominal Organs: The twisting action effectively massages abdominal organs, including the liver and kidneys.
Relieves Mild Back and Hip Pain: Stretching the spine and hips can alleviate tension in these areas.
Boosts Energy: The backbend increases energy and relieves fatigue.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the inside of your left thigh, with your right heel close to your left groin. Keep your left leg straight and your heel extended backward.
On an inhale, lengthen your spine and place your hands at your sides. On an exhale, extend your left arm back, placing your palm on the floor about 9 inches away from your spine. Place your right hand on the outside of your left knee, wrapping your right arm around your left knee.
Keep your spine long, avoiding slouching or arching your back. Gently press your left hand into your left knee to help deepen the twist. Try to extend your right arm back as much as possible, feeling the opening in your shoulder and chest.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breathing and feeling the twist and stretch in your spine. With each inhale, feel the length in your spine; with each exhale, deepen the twist. Look over your left shoulder or at your left fingertips, following the direction of your spinal twist.
On an inhale, slowly return your body to center and release your hands. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Marichi's III
benefits:
Stretches the Spine: Increases spinal flexibility.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Enhances Hip and Knee Flexibility: Deeply stretches the hips and knees.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot near your right glute, with your right shin perpendicular to the floor.
On an inhale, wrap your left arm around your right leg and grab your right wrist from behind. Extend your right arm back, clasping your hands behind your back.
On an exhale, twist your body to the right, moving your right shoulder toward your right knee.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine and the twist in your abdomen.
On an inhale, slowly lift your torso, release your hands, and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Marichi's II
benefits:
Stretches the Spine and Shoulders: Increases spinal flexibility.
Enhances Hip and Knee Flexibility: Deeply stretches the hips and knees.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Strengthens Core: The twisting and forward fold activate the abdominal core.
Improves Breathing Efficiency: The chest expansion helps the practitioner take more complete breaths.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended.
On an exhale, enter Half Lotus Pose by placing your left foot on your right thigh. Bend your right knee so your right shin is perpendicular to the floor and your right foot is flat on the floor.
On an inhale, wrap your right arm around your right leg and grab your left wrist from behind. Extend your left arm back, clasping your hands behind your back.
On an exhale, twist to the left and then fold forward. Keep your spine long, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
On an inhale, slowly lift your torso, release your hands, and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Marichi's I
benefits:
Improves Blood Circulation to Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestive health and relieves constipation.
Stretches the Spine: Increases spinal flexibility, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Enhances Leg Flexibility: Stretches the thighs, calves, and hips, improving leg suppleness.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind and relieve stress.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended in front of you.
On an exhale, bend your left knee and place your left foot near your left glute, with your left shin perpendicular to the floor.
On an inhale, wrap your left arm around your left leg, and with your right hand, grab your left hand from behind, clasping your hands behind your back. Ensure your left knee is as close to your chest as possible and your left foot is stable near your left glute.
On an exhale, twist to the left, moving your right shoulder toward your left knee. Keep your spine long, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back.
Slowly fold your body forward, bringing your abdomen toward your left thigh while keeping your spine long. If your flexibility allows, you can rest your forehead on your left knee.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine and legs.
Slowly lift your torso, release your hands, and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sage Marichi's IV
benefits:
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: Increases spinal length and flexibility.
Improves Spinal Blood Circulation: Promotes blood circulation to the spinal area, relieving back pain.
Stretches the Hips and Knees: Deeply stretches the hips and knees, improving leg suppleness.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Strengthens Core: The twisting and forward fold activate the abdominal core.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on your left thigh to enter Half Lotus Pose. Bend your left knee and place your left foot near your left glute, with your left shin perpendicular to the floor.
On an exhale, twist your body to the left. Wrap your right arm around your left leg and grab your left wrist from behind. Extend your left arm back, clasping your hands behind your back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine and the twist in your abdomen.
On an inhale, slowly lift your torso, release your hands, and return to a seated position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Moon Bird Pose
benefits:
Strengthens Core and Arms: The arm and core support builds strength in the upper body and abdomen.
Stretches the Spine, Hips, and Hamstrings: Deeply stretches the back, hips, and leg muscles.
Enhances Flexibility: Requires high leg and hip flexibility, which helps improve overall suppleness.
Promotes Blood Circulation: Boosts the circulatory system, delivering oxygen-rich blood throughout the body.
Stimulates the Nervous System: Energizes the central nervous system, increasing energy flow.
description:
Start in One-Leg-Behind-the-Head Pose, with one leg (e.g., your right leg) bent and placed behind your head, and the other leg (your left leg) straight.
Place your hands on the floor at your sides, hip-width apart, with your fingers spread and palms facing down.
Press into your hands and use your core strength to lift your glutes off the floor.
Use your core to lift your straight left leg to a 60-75-degree angle from the floor, bringing it as close to your chin as possible.
Maintain a gentle backbend, with your chest open and your breathing steady.
Slowly lower your glutes, remove your right leg from behind your head, and return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Mountain
benefits:
Improves Posture: Helps practitioners establish correct standing posture and correct poor body alignment.
Strengthens Leg Muscles: Builds strength in the thighs, knees, and ankles.
Tones the Abdomen and Glutes: Tightening the core muscles tones the abdomen and glutes.
description:
Start by standing on your mat with your feet together, with your heels and big toes touching. Distribute your body weight evenly across the four corners of your feet (the heels, the balls of your feet, and your toes).
Engage your thigh muscles, lifting your kneecaps to enhance leg stability. Tighten your calf muscles and keep your ankles stable, avoiding any inward or outward rolling of your ankles.
Gently tuck your tailbone to prevent your glutes from sticking out and maintain a neutral pelvic position.
Lift your chest, slightly raising your ribs to prevent a sunken chest. Rotate your shoulders back and press them down, away from your ears, keeping your shoulders relaxed.
Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine. Gently tuck your chin toward your breastbone to maintain the natural curve of your neck.
Place your arms naturally at your sides with your palms facing inward and your fingers relaxed.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stability and strength of your body.
Slowly distribute your body weight evenly on your feet and relax your entire body.

name: Palm Tree Pose
benefits:
Strengthens Legs and Ankles: Supports body weight, improving leg and ankle stability.
Enhances Balance: Requires concentration and body coordination, which helps improve balance.
Improves Posture: Helps correct poor posture and improves an upright stance.
Enhances Core Stability: Activates the abdominal core, improving overall stability.
Relieves Stress: Concentration and deep breathing help relieve stress and anxiety.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The full-body stretch promotes blood circulation.
description:
Start by standing with your feet hip-width apart and your arms relaxed at your sides.
On an inhale, lift your arms overhead, interlocking your fingers and turning your palms toward the ceiling.
Fix your gaze on a point slightly above eye level, keeping your head and neck neutral.
On an inhale, stretch your arms, shoulders, and chest upward, feeling the length in your body.
Feel the stretch from your toes to the crown of your head, and hold the pose for a few seconds to a few minutes.
On an exhale, slowly lower your hands and return to a standing position.

name: Peacock
benefits:
Enhances Balance: The arm support and parallel body position improve balance.
Strengthens Arms, Wrists, and Forearms: Supports body weight, building upper body strength.
Improves Blood Circulation to Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestive health and relieves constipation.
Enhances Focus: Requires a high degree of concentration and balance, which helps improve mental focus.
Activates Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs, improving digestion.
description:
Start by kneeling, with your feet together and your glutes resting on your heels.
Place your hands on the floor, with your fingers pointing toward your body and your hands shoulder-width apart. Bend your elbows and lift your upper arms, resting your chest on your upper arms.
On an inhale, extend your legs back, with your heels lifted and your toes on the floor. On an exhale, lift your legs off the floor and lean your upper body forward, making your body parallel to the floor.
Keep your body in a straight line, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back. Use your abdominal strength to stabilize your body and keep your breathing steady.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your legs back to the floor and relax your entire body.

name: Lotus Peacock
benefits:
Enhances Core Strength: The abdominal engagement significantly strengthens the core.
Strengthens Arms and Wrists: Improves arm and wrist strength, enhancing upper body stability.
Stretches Hips and Wrists: Deeply stretches the hips and wrists, improving body flexibility.
Enhances Balance: Develops body balance and coordination.
description:
Start in Full Lotus Pose, with your legs crossed and your feet on top of the opposite thighs, keeping your spine straight.
On an inhale, extend your hands forward, then place them on the floor with your fingertips pointing backward. Place your hands shoulder-width apart, and bend your elbows, bringing them close to your body to form a support point.
Using the strength of your hands and elbows, lean your body forward, pushing your chest forward to create a 'shelf.' Slowly place your chin on the floor, keeping your spine long.
Engage your abdominal muscles to lift your knees off the floor. At the same time, lift your chin and chest off the floor, finding your balance point.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breath and maintaining balance. Feel the engagement of your core and the strength in your arms and wrists.
Slowly lower your knees back to the floor, bring your hands to your sides, release Lotus Pose, and return to a seated position to rest.

name: Pendant
benefits:
Strengthens the Core, Arms, Wrists, and Shoulders.
Enhances Body Coordination and Balance.
Opens the Chest, Making the Body More Coordinated.
Improves Body Control.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs extended and your hands at your sides.
Bend your knees and bring your feet close to your glutes, with your heels as close to your glutes as possible.
On an inhale, press your hands into the floor, engage your core, and lift your glutes off the floor.
Keep your body balanced and your arms straight. Bring your legs as close to your chest as possible. Point your toes to engage your leg muscles.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
On an exhale, slowly lower your glutes back to the floor.

name: Pigeon
benefits:
Promotes Spinal Blood Circulation: The deep backbend enhances spinal flexibility and blood flow.
Opens the Chest: Expands the chest, helping to improve breathing and relieve tightness.
Strengthens Heart Function: Boosts heart vitality and cardiovascular function.
Stretches the Hips: Relieves hip tension and increases hip joint flexibility.
Promotes Pelvic and Reproductive Organ Health: Stimulates the pelvic area, benefiting the health of the reproductive system.
description:
Start in Reclining Hero Pose. Kneel with your glutes on your heels, then recline backward until your back and head are on the floor.
On an inhale, extend your arms upward, over your head, and place your palms on the floor on either side of your head, with your fingers pointing toward your shoulders.
On an exhale, use the strength of your arms to lift your thighs, torso, and head off the floor, forming a deep backbend. Keep your spine long and stable.
Slowly lower your forearms to the floor and hold your toes with your hands. Gently rest the crown of your head on the floor, keeping your neck comfortable.
Hold the pose with shallow breaths, feeling the stretch in your spine and the opening in your chest.
On an inhale, release your toes, lift your forearms, and slowly return to Reclining Hero Pose, then rest.

name: Flying Pigeon
benefits:
Strengthens the Arms, Shoulders, and Wrists.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of concentration and balance.
Strengthens the Core: Maintaining balance engages the abdominal core.
Opens the Hips: The leg twist increases hip flexibility.
Promotes Digestion: The body twist stimulates abdominal organs, promoting digestion.
Boosts Confidence: Completing this advanced pose can boost the practitioner's self-confidence.
description:
Start in Chair Pose, with your feet together, your knees bent, and your glutes resting on your heels.
Cross your left ankle over your right thigh, with your left foot as close to your right hip joint as possible.
Bend your body forward, placing your hands on the floor with your palms down and your fingers spread. Bend your elbows, bringing your left leg as close to your body as possible.
On an exhale, shift your body weight forward and lift your right leg up and back. Keep your left leg pressing on your forearms to help lift your body and back leg.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your right leg back to the floor and relax your entire body. Repeat on the other side.

name: Sleeping Swan
benefits:
Deeply Opens the Hips: Provides a gentle but effective hip stretch, especially for those who sit for long periods.
Stretches the Front of the Thighs: Effectively stretches the quadriceps and hip flexors, relieving leg tension.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps relax the mind and body, relieving stress.
Improves Flexibility: Long-term practice can significantly enhance hip and leg flexibility.
description:
Start in Half Pigeon Pose, with your right leg in front, your left leg in back, your right knee bent, and your left leg straight with your toes pointing backward.
On an inhale, place your hands at your sides, keeping your spine long. On an exhale, fold forward from your hips, extending your hands forward and placing them on the floor in front of you.
Shift your weight back, ensuring your hip weight is evenly distributed on the floor. Keep your right leg stable and your left leg straight, with your heel extending backward.
Slowly lower your body weight. Place your forearms on the floor first, then your forehead, and finally your chest (adjust according to your flexibility). You can extend your hands forward or place them at your sides, feeling the stretch in your hips and the front of your thighs.
Hold the pose for 3-5 minutes, focusing on deep breaths and feeling the deep stretch in your hips and the front of your thighs. With each exhale, try to relax your hips and legs a bit more.
On an inhale, slowly lift your body, return to Half Pigeon Pose, and repeat on the other side.

name: Mermaid Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Thighs and Hips: Deeply stretches the psoas and thigh muscles, relieving leg tension.
Opens the Shoulders and Chest: The twisting and backbend open the shoulders and chest, improving flexibility.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes blood circulation to abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
Enhances Balance: Develops body balance and coordination.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps relax the mind and body, relieving stress.
description:
Start in a seated position, with your hips facing forward and your legs straight.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the inside of your left thigh, with your right heel close to your left groin (if your flexibility allows, you can straighten your right leg at a 90-degree angle to the floor). Extend your left leg back, bend your left knee, and extend your left heel backward. Hook the inside of your left foot with your left elbow.
On an inhale, extend your left arm upward, bend your left elbow so your left forearm is perpendicular to the floor, and your left upper arm is close to your ear. Wrap your right arm behind your back and clasp your hands behind your back to form a 'bind' (if you can't clasp, you can use a yoga strap).
Keep your hips facing forward, avoiding one hip lifting. Slowly twist your upper body to the right, feeling the opening in your chest and shoulders. Keep your spine long, avoiding a sunken lower back.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breath and feeling the stretch and twist in your body. With each inhale, feel the length in your spine; with each exhale, deepen the twist.
On an inhale, slowly return your body to center and release your hands. Repeat on the other side.

name: Half Pigeon
benefits:
Deeply Stretches the Hips: Half Pigeon Pose effectively opens the hips, relieving tension from prolonged sitting.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The leg twist and back extension improve spinal flexibility.
Relieves Stress: The hips are a place where emotional stress is stored. Half Pigeon Pose helps release pent-up emotions through deep stretching.
Improves Body Balance and Stability: Practicing Half Pigeon Pose can build strength in the legs and hips, improving overall balance.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog, with your hands and feet supporting you on the floor and your body in an inverted 'V' shape.
On an inhale, bend your right leg forward and place it between your hands, with your right knee near your right hand and your right ankle near your left hand. Extend your left leg back, with the top of your foot on the floor, keeping your hips aligned to the front.
Keep your front leg bent, and try to keep your hips parallel to the floor. If your hips feel tight, you can place a yoga block or blanket under your right hip to help find balance.
On an inhale, support yourself with your hands on either side of your body, lengthening your spine and keeping your back straight. Lift your chest upward. Relax your shoulders, keeping them away from your ears.
Hold the pose for 5-8 deep, long breaths. With each inhale, feel the length in your spine; with each exhale, relax your hips and allow them to sink into the pose.
On an exhale, support yourself with your hands on the floor, slowly lift your body, return to Downward-Facing Dog, and repeat on the other side.

name: One Legged King Pigeon
benefits:
Stretches the Thighs and Hips: Deeply stretches the thighs, hips, and psoas.
Opens the Shoulders and Chest: The backbend opens the shoulders and chest.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: Improves spinal flexibility and strength.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes blood circulation to abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
description:
Start in Half Pigeon Pose, with your right leg bent forward, your right foot near your left groin, and your left leg extended back with the top of your foot on the floor.
On an inhale, place your hands at your sides, push your chest forward, and lengthen your neck. On an exhale, extend your hands back and grab your left ankle or toes.
Bend your left knee, pull your left foot toward your head, and make your left shin perpendicular to the floor. Bend your right hand upward and grab the top of your left foot or your left ankle. Bend your left hand upward and stack it with your right hand, wrapping your hands around your left foot and head.
Keep your hips facing forward, avoiding one hip lifting. Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breath and feeling the stretch and balance in your body.
