Release your hands one by one, return your body to center, straighten your legs, and return to Staff Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: King Pigeon
benefits:
Opens the Hips and Shoulders: Deeply stretches the hips, shoulders, and chest, improving flexibility.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The backbend enhances spinal flexibility.
Enhances Balance: Develops body balance and coordination.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes blood circulation to abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
description:
Start in Staff Pose, with your legs straight on the floor.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the inside of your left thigh, with your right heel close to your left groin. Extend your left leg back, with the front of your left thigh, knee, shin, and the top of your toes on the floor.
On an inhale, place your hands at your sides, push your chest forward, and lengthen your neck. On an exhale, extend your hands back and grab your left ankle, pulling your left foot toward your head.
Bend your right hand upward and grab the top of your left foot or your left ankle. Bend your left hand upward and stack it with your right hand, wrapping your hands around your left foot and head. Keep your hips facing forward, avoiding one hip lifting.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, focusing on your breath and feeling the stretch and balance in your body. With each inhale, feel the length in your spine; with each exhale, deepen the twist.
Release your hands one by one, return your body to center, straighten your legs, and return to Staff Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: Plank Pose
benefits:
Strengthens Arms, Wrists, and Spine.
Tones the Abdomen: Engages the core, improving abdominal firmness.
Enhances Core Stability: The core engagement improves body balance.
Improves Posture: Helps correct poor posture and improves overall body alignment.
Relieves Stress: The body extension helps relieve stress and improves mental state.
description:
Start in Downward-Facing Dog, with your hands and feet on the floor, forming an inverted 'V' shape with your body.
Place your hands directly under your shoulders, with your palms down and your fingers spread, pressing into the floor. Keep your elbows close to your sides, ensuring your wrists, elbows, and shoulders are in a straight line.
Separate your feet to hip-width apart. Press your heels back and flex your toes to engage your leg muscles. Keep your ankles stable, avoiding any inward or outward rolling.
Engage your core, pulling your navel toward your spine to activate your core muscles. Gently tuck your tailbone to prevent your glutes from sticking out and maintain a neutral pelvis.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, tighten your abdomen a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stability and strength of your body.
Slowly shift your body weight forward, return to Downward-Facing Dog, or go directly into Child's Pose to relax.

name: Dolphin Plank Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Arms, Wrists, Core, and Leg Muscles.
Improves Posture: Stretches the spine, strengthens back muscles, and improves body alignment.
Promotes Digestion: Applies pressure to abdominal organs, promoting digestion and reducing constipation.
Enhances Balance: Improves balance and body stability.
Relieves Stress: The full-body stretch and relaxation help reduce stress and anxiety.
description:
Start in Tabletop Pose, with your hands under your shoulders and your knees under your hips. On an inhale, place your forearms on the floor, with your elbows aligned with your shoulders and your hands pressing into the floor.
On an inhale, engage your core and lift your knees and thighs, entering Forearm Plank. Press your toes into the floor and extend your heels backward, keeping your legs straight.
Keep your shoulders directly over your elbows, avoiding shrugging your shoulders. Press your outer arms inward and spread your shoulder blades away from your spine. Tighten your abdominal muscles, pulling your navel toward your spine to keep your back flat.
Keep your body in a straight line from your head to your heels, avoiding your glutes being too high or sagging. Breathe naturally, feeling the stability and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your knees back to the floor and return to Tabletop Pose. Rest for a moment or enter Child's Pose to relax.

name: Side Plank
benefits:
Strengthens the Arms, Legs, and Core.
Stretches the Shoulders, Hamstrings, Calves, and Foot Arches.
Relieves Stress and Mild Depression: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind.
Improves Digestive Function: Massages abdominal organs, relieving indigestion.
Relieves Headaches, Insomnia, Back Pain, and Fatigue: The body extension helps relieve these discomforts.
Helps with Hypertension, Asthma, Flat Feet, and Sciatica: Provides a supportive role for these conditions.
description:
Start in Plank Pose, with your hands and feet supporting you on the floor and your body in a straight line.
Shift your body weight to one side (e.g., your right side), with your right arm and right foot supporting your body weight. Extend your left hand upward, with your palm facing forward and your fingers spread. Stack your left foot on top of your right foot.
Press the outer edge of your right foot into the floor, using your heel and toes to grip the floor and keep your leg stable. If your foot flexibility is limited, you can place your body weight on the outer edge of your right foot instead of the entire sole.
Press your right hand into the floor. Extend your left arm upward, squeezing your shoulder blades back and down, then spreading them away from your spine. Your left arm and right arm should form a straight line, keeping your body balanced.
Engage your core, keeping your abdomen tight and avoiding your lower back from sagging. Extend the crown of your head upward and gaze at your left fingertips.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths.
Slowly lower your left arm, return to Plank Pose, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Upward Plank
benefits:
Strengthens the Arms, Wrists, and Legs.
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, and the Front of the Ankles.
Enhances Core Stability.
Improves Posture and Balance.
description:
Start by sitting on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Place your hands on the floor behind you, with your fingers pointing toward your toes.
Before starting, engage your glutes, core, and arm muscles. This will help you control your body better and avoid unnecessary injuries.
Use the strength of your glutes, core, and arms to lift your glutes off the floor until your body forms a straight line from your heels to your shoulders. Ensure your shoulders are relaxed and pulled down, avoiding shrugging. At the same time, avoid your glutes from sagging and keep your abdomen slightly contracted to maintain body stability.
Try to hold this reversed plank pose for 20 to 30 seconds, or as long as you can while maintaining the correct posture.
Slowly lower your glutes and body back to the floor, returning to a seated position.

name: Plow Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Spine: Deeply stretches the back, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inverted pose allows blood to flow to the head, bringing a sense of relaxation and clarity.
Regulates the Digestive System: The compression on abdominal organs relieves indigestion and bloating.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Directing blood flow to the brain helps calm the mind.
Stimulates the Thyroid: The inverted pose promotes blood circulation in the neck, improving thyroid function.
description:
Start by lying on your back on your mat, with your legs straight and your arms at your sides with your palms down.
On an inhale, slowly lift your legs until they are perpendicular to the floor. Continue to lift your glutes, supporting your back with your hands to keep your spine straight. On an inhale, swing your legs over your head to the floor, with your toes touching the floor. If possible, try to flatten your feet completely.
You can continue to support your back with your arms, or you can straighten your arms, with your palms on the floor and your fingers interlocked (adjust according to your flexibility).
Hold the pose for 30 seconds to a few minutes, adjusting to your personal comfort level. Keep your breathing steady, avoiding holding your breath.
On an inhale, slowly lift your legs back to a vertical position. Support your back and gradually lower your legs back to the starting supine position. Relax your breathing and feel the stretch from the pose.

name: Prayer Pose
benefits:
Mind-Body Connection: The prayer hands symbolize the balance and unity of the left and right brain, helping the mind and body enter a state of calm.
Enhances Balance: Whether as a Mountain Pose prayer or a transition between other poses, it helps develop body stability and balance.
Calms Emotions: Focusing on your breath and the prayer hands helps calm emotions and relieve tension and anxiety.
Stretches the Shoulders and Chest: When in prayer pose, appropriately opening the chest can gently stretch the shoulder and chest muscles, improving posture.
description:
Start by standing in Mountain Pose (Tadasana), with your feet together, your body straight, and your shoulders relaxed.
Gently engage your core and keep your pelvis neutral to stabilize your core.
On an inhale, lift your hands from your sides or bring them together in front of your chest.
Bring your hands together in Anjali Mudra (prayer pose) in front of your chest, with your thumbs gently touching your sternum.
Relax your shoulders, allowing your shoulder blades to naturally sink down, avoiding shrugging your shoulders.
Maintain steady breathing, feel the pressure between your palms, and gaze at a point in front of you to keep your body stable.
On an exhale, slowly lower your hands and return to Mountain Pose.

name: Half Bow
benefits:
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, Thighs, Groin, and Abdomen.
Strengthens the Legs and Ankles.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility.
Massages Abdominal Organs, Promoting Digestion.
Opens the Chest, Improving Posture.
description:
Start by lying on your stomach on your mat, with your legs straight, your arms at your sides, and your forehead gently resting on the floor.
On an inhale, bend your right knee and use your right hand to grab your right ankle or foot from behind.
On an inhale, use the strength of your right leg and right hand to lift your right knee upward. At the same time, lift your chest and right thigh off the floor. Keep your left leg straight and on the floor. Your left arm can extend forward to help with balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your shoulders and hips a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your right knee and chest, returning to the prone position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Extended Puppy
benefits:
Stretches the Spine and Shoulders: Effectively relieves tension in the back and shoulders.
Enhances Flexibility: Increases spinal suppleness, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind and relieve stress.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inverted pose helps promote blood flow to the head, improving mental state.
description:
Start in Tabletop Pose, with your hands directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips.
On an inhale, lift your glutes upward, forming an inverted 'V' shape. Extend your hands forward, with your palms down and pressing into the floor, feeling the length in your spine.
Slowly place your forehead, chest, or chin on the floor. Keep your arms straight, pressing into the floor to deepen the stretch. Ensure your hips are at a 90-degree angle to your knees, and move your hips backward, closer to your heels.
Keep your shins and the tops of your feet on the floor, maintaining stability. Keep the natural curve of your spine, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back. Look forward, keeping your neck relaxed.
Slowly lower your glutes, return to Tabletop Pose, or go into Child's Pose to relax.

name: Half Splits
benefits:
Stretches the Legs: Deeply stretches the hamstrings and quadriceps, relieving leg tension.
Strengthens Leg Muscles: Works the thigh muscles, improving leg stability.
Opens the Hip Joints: Promotes hip joint flexibility, relieving hip stiffness.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Improves digestive function and promotes bowel movements.
Relieves Lower Back Pain: Soothes lower back tension and stabilizes the pelvis.
description:
Start in Crescent Pose, with your front leg bent, your back leg straight, and your hands on either side of your front leg.
On an exhale, place your back knee on the mat and the top of your back foot on the floor, extending your toes backward. Slowly slide your front leg forward, straightening it and flexing your toes back, ensuring your front leg is perpendicular to the floor.
On an inhale, lengthen your spine and place your hands on either side of your front leg or use yoga blocks for support. On an exhale, fold forward from your hips, bringing your hands closer to the floor and keeping your spine long.
Keep your hips facing forward, pulling your front hip back and pushing your back hip forward to ensure both hips are level. Feel the stretch in the back of your thigh and your hips. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
On an inhale, slowly lift your body and bring your hands back to your sides. Repeat on the other side.

name: Pyramid Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, Hips, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Strengthens Leg Muscles: Supports body weight, building strength in the legs.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of concentration and balance.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Promotes Digestion: Stimulates abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
description:
Start in Mountain Pose, with your feet hip-width apart and your hands at your sides.
Step your left foot back a large step, with your feet about two and a half shoulder-widths apart. Slightly angle your left toes inward. Keep your right foot forward and your left foot back, maintaining a stable stance.
On an inhale, place your hands on your hips and lift your chest and head. On an exhale, fold your body forward from your hip joints, placing your hands on the floor on either side of your right foot, with your palms down.
Keep your spine long, avoiding excessive arching in your lower back. You can place your hands on either side of your right foot or hold your right shin, adjusting to your personal flexibility. Hold for about 30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your spine and legs.
On an inhale, slowly lift your head and straighten your back and elbows. On another inhale, lift your body with control, returning to Mountain Pose.

name: Rabbit Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, Hips, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Strengthens Abdominal Muscles: Engages the core, improving abdominal firmness.
Increases Blood Flow to the Brain: Promotes blood circulation to the head, relieving headaches and insomnia.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Promotes Digestion: Massages abdominal organs, improving digestive function.
Improves Posture: Stretching the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start in Vajrasana (Thunderbolt Pose), with your feet together and your glutes resting on your heels.
On an inhale, reach back with your hands to grab your ankles or heels, with your palms facing up.
On an inhale, fold your body forward, gently touching your forehead to the floor. Flex your toes, arch your back, and slightly lift your glutes, feeling the stretch in your spine.
Hold the pose with natural breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine; with each exhale, relax your shoulders and hips a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your neck, shoulders, and back.
On an exhale, slowly lift your body and return to Vajrasana.

name: Rag Doll Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Hamstrings and Calves: Gently stretches the hamstrings and calves, relieving leg tension.
Relaxes the Neck and Shoulders: The forward fold relaxes the neck and shoulder muscles.
Relieves Fatigue: Suitable for relaxation after practice, relieving body tension and fatigue.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The forward fold promotes blood flow to the head, improving cerebral blood supply.
description:
Start in Standing Forward Bend (Uttanasana), with your feet hip-width apart and your hands at your sides.
On an inhale, extend your hands to the sides, then cross your arms and grab the opposite elbows. Slowly fold your body forward, letting your upper body hang naturally, with your chest as close to your thighs as possible.
You can slightly bend your knees to ease the hamstring stretch, allowing your chest to rest on your thighs. Shift your body weight slightly forward to the balls of your feet, lifting your sit bones upward to feel the stretch in your legs. Relax your neck and facial muscles, letting your head hang naturally.
Hold the pose for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your legs and the relaxation in your neck. You can gently sway your body from side to side to release more tension.
On an inhale, slowly lift your body, bring your hands back to your sides, and return to a standing position.

name: Raised Legs Pose
benefits:
Opens the Chest, Throat, and Abdomen: The backbend expands the chest, increasing lung capacity, while stretching the throat and abdominal area.
Strengthens the Core: Lifting the legs requires core engagement, effectively working the abdominal muscles.
Enhances Balance: Maintaining body balance during the pose helps improve coordination and stability.
Relieves Shoulder and Neck Tension: As a variation of Fish Pose, it can relieve shoulder and neck tension after Shoulderstand.
description:
Start in Fish Pose. Lie on your back on your mat with your legs together and your hands at your sides. Slide your hands back, placing them under your glutes, with your palms down and your fingers pointing forward.
On an inhale, use the strength of your abdomen and back to lift your chest, resting your body weight on your forearms. Arch your head back, with the crown of your head gently touching the floor, but don't place your weight on your head.
Extend your hands forward, with your palms facing each other in Anjali Mudra (Prayer Pose) in front of your chest.
On an inhale, slowly lift your legs, trying to keep them straight, and flex your toes to engage your leg muscles. If this is difficult, you can lift one leg first, then the other.
Adjust your gaze according to your flexibility. You can look at the sky or the back of the room. If your neck feels uncomfortable, you can choose to look forward.
Hold the pose with steady breaths, feeling the stretch in your chest, throat, and abdomen. Hold for 5-10 breaths.
On an inhale, slowly lower your legs, return to a supine position, bring your hands back to your sides, and relax your entire body.

name: Reclining Staff Pose
benefits:
Relaxes the Spine and Lower Back: Relieves tension and fatigue in the spine and lower back.
Promotes Body Recovery: Helps the body relax and promotes overall recovery.
Relieves Stress: Deep relaxation helps relieve physical and mental stress, bringing inner peace.
Improves Blood Circulation: Promotes blood circulation in the lower limbs, relieving leg fatigue.
Soothes the Nervous System: Helps relax the nervous system, reducing anxiety and fatigue.
description:
Start by lying on your back on the floor, allowing your back to relax naturally against the floor.
Lift your legs straight up, making them as perpendicular to the floor as possible, avoiding tension in the backs of your knees.
Keep your legs extended, but don't overdo it to avoid muscle tension.
Place your arms naturally at your sides, with your palms facing up and your fingers naturally spread, entering a state of relaxation.
Gently close your eyes, focusing your gaze inward, and enter a state of deep relaxation.
Stay in this pose for 5-10 deep breaths, feeling your body relax.
(Optional) Gently sway your legs from side to side to further relax your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your legs, returning to a supine position, and relax your entire body.

name: Elbow Balance
benefits:
Strengthens the Upper Body, Shoulders, and Core.
Enhances Balance and Focus.
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, and Back.
Promotes Blood Circulation and Relieves Stress.
description:
Start in Dolphin Pose, with your hands on the floor, your forearms on the floor, and your elbows shoulder-width apart.
Press your hands into the floor, engage your core, and lift your glutes, forming an inverted 'V' shape. Slowly lift one leg (e.g., your right leg) toward your head, keeping your leg straight.
Once your right leg is stable, lift your other leg (your left leg) as well, bringing your legs together and making them perpendicular to the floor. Keep your forearms and palms pressing into the floor, ensuring your body weight is on your forearms.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
Slowly lower one leg (e.g., your right leg), then the other leg (your left leg), back to Dolphin Pose. Rest for a moment and relax your entire body.

name: Reverse Corpse
benefits:
Relieves Back and Neck Pain: Relaxes back and neck muscles, reducing tension and pain.
Deeply Relaxes the Body: Helps the entire body enter a state of deep relaxation, relieving muscle tension.
Soothes the Nervous System: Activates the parasympathetic nervous system, reducing stress and anxiety.
Promotes Digestion: Conscious breathing massages abdominal organs, promoting digestion.
Activates the Energy Center: Stimulates the Manipura Chakra (Navel Chakra) in the abdominal area, balancing digestive function.
description:
Start by lying face down on your mat with your legs extended behind you.
Gently place your forehead on the floor, keeping your neck neutral.
Extend your arms forward, placing them in front of your head with your palms together.
Close your eyes and take deep, long, and even breaths, feeling your body relax.
Progressively relax every part of your body, from your head to your feet.
Hold the pose for 5-10 minutes, or longer if needed.
After the practice, gently move your fingers and toes, then slowly return to a comfortable state.

name: Reverse Table
benefits:
Strengthens Arms, Wrists, and Legs: Supports body weight, building strength in these areas.
Stretches Shoulders, Chest, and the Front of the Ankles: Helps open the shoulders and chest, increasing body flexibility.
Enhances Core Stability: Engages the abdominal core, improving overall stability.
Improves Posture: The stretching and strengthening of back muscles help correct poor posture.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inverted pose helps promote blood flow to the head and upper limbs, relieving fatigue.
description:
Start in a seated position on your mat, with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor, close to your glutes.
Place your hands on the floor about 30 cm behind your body, with your fingers pointing forward, toward your glutes.
Keep your knees bent and your feet close to your glutes, with your heels as close to your sit bones as possible.
Pressing your hands and feet into the floor, lift your hips to form an inverted 'U' shape.
Ensure your body weight is evenly distributed between your hands and feet, avoiding overexertion.
Gently arch your head back, gazing at the tip of your nose, keeping your neck relaxed.
Hold the pose for 5-10 deep breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your hips back to the floor, returning to a seated position.

name: Rooster
benefits:
Strengthens the Core, Arms, Shoulders, Elbows, and Wrists.
Enhances Flexibility in the Hips, Knees, and Ankles.
Enhances Balance and Focus.
Promotes Digestive Function: The abdominal compression improves the digestive system.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching and breathing help calm the mind.
description:
Start in Full Lotus Pose, with your legs crossed and your feet on top of the opposite thighs, with your hands at your sides.
Place your hands at your sides, with your fingers spread and your palms down. Slowly move your hands back, threading them through your legs and placing them between your thighs and shins.
On an inhale, shift your body weight forward, press your hands into the floor, and engage your core. Slowly lift your glutes off the floor, keeping your legs in Lotus Pose.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
Slowly lower your glutes, return to Full Lotus Pose, and relax your entire body.

name: Shoulder Pressing
benefits:
Strengthens the Arms and Wrists.
Stretches the Upper Back.
Strengthens the Abdominal Muscles and Hip Flexors.
Opens the Hips.
Enhances Balance and Focus.
description:
Start in a squat (e.g., Garland Pose), with your feet wider than your hips and your toes turned out.
Thread your hands backward through your legs and place them on the floor behind your ankles, with your palms down, fingers spread, and fingertips pointing forward. If needed, you can slightly lift your glutes to help thread your hands through your legs.
On an inhale, move your upper arms as high as possible, close to your knees, to form a support point. Bend your elbows to create a 'shelf.' Shift your body weight forward, transferring it to your palms.
Slowly lift one foot (e.g., your right foot), then lift the other foot (your left foot), and cross your feet. Maintain body balance, keeping your feet off the floor as much as possible, feeling the strength in your arms and core.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
Slowly lower your feet, return to a squat, and relax your entire body.
aka_chinese: ['腿交叉双臂支撑式','夹上臂式','夹肩式']

name: Scorpion
benefits:
Strengthens the Shoulders, Arms, and Core.
Stretches the Spine, Hips, and Neck.
Enhances Balance and Focus.
Promotes Blood Circulation and Relieves Stress.
Boosts Self-Confidence and Overcomes Fear.
description:
Start in Feathered Peacock Pose. Place your forearms on the floor, with your elbows shoulder-width apart, and press your hands into the floor with your fingers spread.
On an inhale, lift your legs toward your head, keeping them straight. Once your body is stable, on an exhale, bend your knees and move your feet toward your head, bringing your heels as close to the crown of your head as possible.
Keep your neck long, lifting your head to avoid neck pressure. Squeeze your shoulder blades back, keep your shoulders away from your ears, and press your forearms and palms into the floor to maintain balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for about 30 seconds, adjusting to your personal ability.
Slowly lower your feet, return to Feathered Peacock Pose, and then rest in Child's Pose.

name: Seated Forward Bend I
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs, relieving indigestion.
Enhances Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
On an inhale, extend your hands upward, lengthening your spine and lifting your chest. Keep your spine long and fold your body forward from your hip joints, extending your hands toward your toes.
Grab your big toes with your index and middle fingers, keeping your back flat and avoiding arching your lower back. If you can't reach your toes, you can grab your ankles or shins, or use a yoga strap.
Bring your lower ribs close to your thighs, keeping your back flat, even if you need to bend your knees to keep your spine long. Internally rotate your thighs, bringing your big toes toward the center of your body. Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch and relaxation of your body.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to a seated position, and relax your entire body.

name_en: 半莲花加强背部前屈伸展式
name: Seated Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend
benefits:
Stretches the Back, Hamstrings, Hips, and Spine: Effectively relieves tension in these areas.
Opens the Chest and Shoulders: Improves upper body flexibility.
Relieves Constipation: The abdominal compression promotes bowel movements.
Relieves Lower Back Pain: The stretching and relaxation of back muscles reduce pressure on the lower back.
Improves Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start in Staff Pose, with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot on your left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible, with the top of your foot tight against your thigh, forming Half Lotus Pose.
On an inhale, wrap your right hand behind your body to grab your right big toe (if you can't reach, you can grab your ankle). Extend your left hand forward. On an inhale, lengthen your spine and lift your chest.
On an exhale, fold your body forward from your hip joints, trying to straighten your left arm, with your hands aligned with your toes. Keep your spine long, avoiding arching your lower back, and bring your head close to your right knee.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, adjusting to your personal ability.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to Staff Pose, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Seated Forward Bend II
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Enhances Internal Rotation of the Legs: Pressing on the big toes helps internally rotate the thighs, improving leg stability.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs, relieving indigestion.
Enhances Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
On an inhale, extend your hands upward, lengthening your spine and lifting your chest. Keep your spine long and fold your body forward from your hip joints, extending your hands toward your toes.
Wrap your hands around the outer sides of your feet and press your thumbs into your big toes to help internally rotate your thighs.
Bring your lower ribs close to your thighs, keeping your back flat and avoiding arching your lower back. Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch and relaxation of your body.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to a seated position, and relax your entire body.

name: Seated Forward Bend III
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Enhances Internal Rotation of the Legs: Pressing on the big toes helps internally rotate the thighs, improving leg stability.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs, relieving indigestion.
Enhances Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
On an inhale, extend your hands upward, lengthening your spine and lifting your chest. Keep your spine long and fold your body forward from your hip joints, extending your hands toward your toes.
Wrap your hands around the soles of your feet and press your toes.
Bring your lower ribs close to your thighs, keeping your back flat and avoiding arching your lower back. Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch and relaxation of your body.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to a seated position, and relax your entire body.

name: Seated Forward Bend IV
benefits:
Stretches the Spine, Shoulders, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Enhances Internal Rotation of the Legs: Pressing on the big toes helps internally rotate the thighs, improving leg stability.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Digestive Function: Stimulates abdominal organs, relieving indigestion.
Enhances Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
On an inhale, extend your hands upward, lengthening your spine and lifting your chest. Keep your spine long and fold your body forward from your hip joints, extending your hands toward your toes.
Place your hands on the soles of your feet, with your fingers spread and your palms on the soles. With one hand (e.g., your right hand), grab the wrist of your other hand (your left hand) and hold this pose. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, then switch sides and grab your right wrist with your left hand.
Bring your lower ribs close to your thighs, keeping your back flat and avoiding arching your lower back. Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 minutes, feeling the stretch and relaxation of your body.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to a seated position, and relax your entire body.

name: Seated Three Limbed Forward Bend
benefits:
Enhances Flexibility in the Ankles, Knees, and Hips: Effectively relieves tension in these areas.
Strengthens Abdominal Muscles: The forward fold activates the abdominal core.
Improves Digestive Function: The abdominal compression promotes bowel movements.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Enhances Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight and together, your toes flexed back, and your sit bones rooted to the floor.
Tilt your body to one side (e.g., to the left), bend your right knee, and place your right foot on the inside of your left thigh, as close to your left hip joint as possible, forming Hero Pose (Virasana). The top of your right foot should be tight against your left thigh, and your right shin should be perpendicular to the floor.
Engage your right knee and press your right thigh down, keeping your legs in contact. If your pelvis is tilted to one side, you can place a folded blanket under your right glute to help balance your hips.
On an inhale, extend your hands upward, lengthening your spine and lifting your chest. On an exhale, fold your body forward from your hip joints, grabbing your left foot with your hands (if you can't reach, you can use a yoga strap).
Bring your chest close to your left leg, keeping your back concave and avoiding arching your lower back. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your hips and legs a bit more. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, adjusting to your personal ability.
Slowly lift your upper body, return to a seated position, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Noose Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Legs and Ankles.
Enhances Flexibility in the Spine, Shoulders, and Ankles.
Expands the Chest: The twisting motion opens the chest, improving respiratory function.
Massages Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Stimulates the Liver, Spleen, and Pancreas: Improves the function of internal organs.
Relieves Sciatica: The twisting motion reduces pressure on the sciatic nerve.
description:
Start in a squat, with your feet together, your heels on the floor, and your glutes as close to your heels as possible.
On an exhale, twist your body to the right. Bring your left upper arm to the outside of your right thigh, bend your left elbow, and wrap your left forearm through your legs. Extend your right hand back, wrapping it around your body to grab your left wrist or fingers.
Ensure your left arm is tight against the outside of your right thigh, your left elbow is bent, and your left forearm is wrapped through your legs. Your right hand grabs your left wrist from behind, forming a 'bind.' Keep your spine long, avoiding arching your lower back, and turn your head to the right.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, deepen the twist a bit more. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, adjusting to your personal ability.
On an exhale, slowly release your hands, return to a squat, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Shiva Squat
benefits:
Strengthens the Legs, Knees, and Ankles.
Stretches the Calves and Thighs.
Enhances Balance and Focus.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The bending and stretching of the legs promote blood flow to the legs and feet.
description:
Start by standing with your feet hip-width apart and your hands in Anjali Mudra (Prayer Pose) in front of your chest.
Shift your body weight to one foot (e.g., your right foot). Move the knee of your other foot (your left foot) backward, placing it behind your right foot.
Bend both knees, trying to move your hips forward and keep your hips level. Ensure your hips are facing forward, avoiding twisting.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the strength and balance in your legs.
Slowly move your left foot back to the starting position. Repeat on the other side.

name: Shiva Squat with Prayer Hands
benefits:
Stretches the Calves and Thighs: Effectively stretches the calf and thigh muscles, relieving leg tension.
Strengthens the Legs: Builds strength in the legs, knees, and ankles, improving body stability.
Enhances Balance: The combination of a deep squat and Prayer Pose enhances body balance and focus.
Promotes Digestion: The squat pose can massage abdominal organs, promoting digestion.
description:
Start in Tadasana (Mountain Pose), with your feet together and your hands in Anjali Mudra (Prayer Pose) in front of your chest.
On an inhale, separate your feet to be slightly wider than your hips, with your toes naturally turned out. On an exhale, bend your knees and sit back with your glutes, keeping your spine straight.
While squatting, keep both feet flat on the floor, with your heels not lifting. Keep your hands in Anjali Mudra, either in front of your chest or at your heart chakra, feeling the stability of your hands. Ensure your knees are aligned with your toes, avoiding any inward or outward rotation.
Hold the squat pose, feeling the strength in your legs and ankles. Take 3-5 deep breaths, focusing on your body's stability and balance.
On an inhale, slowly straighten your legs and stand up. Bring your hands back to your sides and return to Tadasana.

name: Shoulder Stand with Lotus Legs
benefits:
Opens the Hips and Groin: Effectively stretches the hips and groin, relieving stiffness from prolonged sitting.
Stretches the Knees, Ankles, and Thighs: Enhances leg flexibility.
Strengthens the Legs and Glutes: Supports body weight, strengthening the leg and glute muscles.
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inverted pose helps promote blood flow back to the heart, reducing leg swelling.
Enhances Balance and Focus: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
description:
Start in Shoulderstand. You can support your back with your hands or place your arms naturally at your sides.
On an inhale, extend your legs upward, then slowly cross your feet into Lotus Pose. Place your right foot at the base of your left thigh and your left foot at the base of your right thigh.
Keep your spine long and your hips facing forward, avoiding twisting. You can continue to support your lower back with your hands or place your arms naturally at your sides to maintain balance.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more.
Slowly unbind the Lotus Pose, lower your legs, and return to Shoulderstand, then gradually return to a supine position.

name: Supported Shoulder Stand
benefits:
Promotes Blood Circulation: The inverted pose directs blood flow to the head and upper body, improving cerebral blood supply, while also promoting blood flow back from the lower limbs.
Strengthens the Core: The core must be stable to balance the entire body in Shoulderstand, effectively building core strength.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: Helps stretch and lengthen the spine while relieving spinal pressure.
Relaxes the Nervous System: A stable inverted pose can relax the nervous system, reducing stress and anxiety.
Regulates the Endocrine System: Stimulating the thyroid helps balance hormone secretion and promotes metabolism.
description:
Start by lying on your back on your mat, with your legs together and your arms at your sides, palms down.
On an inhale, lift both legs together, pointing your toes toward the ceiling, keeping your legs straight.
Continue to lift your legs upward, simultaneously raising your hips and lower back off the floor. Support your back with your hands, with your elbows on the floor and your palms gently holding your lower back.
Straighten your legs toward the ceiling, pointing your toes up and keeping your legs together and engaged. Your hands should provide stable support for your back, your shoulders and upper arms should bear your body weight, and your head and neck should be relaxed.
Keep your spine long, with your body and legs in a straight line, perpendicular to the floor. Gently tuck your chin toward your chest, creating a 'throat lock,' which helps stimulate the thyroid and protect your neck.
Hold the pose with deep, steady breaths. With each inhale, feel the stretch in your back and legs; with each exhale, feel your body relax and stabilize. You can hold for 5 to 10 deep breaths, or longer as you feel comfortable.
To exit the pose, slowly lower your legs, bringing them toward your head, then roll your spine down, gradually returning your upper back and hips to the floor.

name: Unsupported Shoulder Stand
benefits:
Promotes Blood Circulation: Increases blood flow to the head and upper body, improving cerebral blood supply.
Strengthens the Core: Builds strength in the abdominal, back, and glute muscles.
Relieves Stress and Fatigue: Relaxes the nervous system, alleviating anxiety and insomnia.
Regulates the Endocrine System: Stimulates the thyroid, balancing hormone secretion.
description:
Start by lying on your back on your mat, with your legs together and your arms at your sides, palms down.
On an inhale, engage your abdomen and lift your legs to be perpendicular to the floor. On an exhale, lift your hips off the floor, raising your spine one vertebra at a time, and extending your legs upward, keeping your back straight. On an inhale, tuck your chin, lift your chest, and try to fully straighten your legs, so your body is at a 90-degree angle to your head.
Remove your hands from your back and slowly straighten your arms upward, with your palms close to the outer sides of your thighs. Ensure your shoulders and neck are stable, avoiding excessive neck pressure.
Hold the pose with natural breaths, feeling the balance and stability of your body. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute, or adjust as you feel comfortable.
To exit the pose, bend your elbows and return your hands to your back. Slowly lower your body until your hips touch the floor. Avoid lowering your legs and back too quickly.

name: Side Lunge
benefits:
Strengthens the Core: Engaging the core muscles to maintain balance.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
Stretches the Hips and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves leg tension.
Relieves and Prevents Back Pain and Sciatica: The stretching and strengthening of leg muscles reduce pressure on the back.
description:
Start by standing with your feet wider than your shoulders and your legs straight.
Turn your right foot out 90 degrees and your left foot in about 15 degrees.
Bend your right knee, pointing your right toes outward and bringing your right heel as close to your right hip as possible. Keep your left leg straight, with your left toes pointing forward and your left heel pressing into the floor.
On an inhale, straighten your spine, avoiding arching your lower back. Engage your right quadriceps and hamstrings to keep your right knee stable. Press both your left and right heels into the floor, feeling the strength in your legs.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, stabilize your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the strength in your legs and the stretch in your hips.
Slowly straighten your right knee, return to the starting position, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Snake Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Spine, Glutes, and Back.
Stretches the Shoulders, Chest, Abdomen, and Thighs.
Improves Respiratory Function: Opening the chest increases lung capacity.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start by lying face down on your mat, with your legs together, your toes flexed back, and your heels pressing into the floor.
Place your hands at your sides, with your palms up and your fingers spread. On an inhale, move your hands backward, placing them under your waist, with your fingers interlaced and your palms up.
On an inhale, use the strength of your abdomen and back to lift your chest off the floor, lifting your chest as high as you can. At the same time, lift your interlaced hands upward and backward, feeling the lengthening of your spine and the opening of your shoulders.
Keep your legs engaged, with your inner thighs close to each other and your big toes touching. Keep your neck long, in a straight line with your spine, avoiding excessive neck arching. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your shoulders and abdomen a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your spine.
Slowly lower your chest, return to a face-down position, and relax your entire body.

name: Sphinx Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Spine: The backbend strengthens the spine and back muscles.
Stretches the Chest, Lungs, Shoulders, and Abdomen: Opens the chest, increasing lung capacity.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Relieves Back Pain: The stretching of the spine reduces pressure on the lower back.
Improves Respiratory Function: Opening the chest improves breathing efficiency.
description:
Start by lying face down on your mat, with your legs together and the tops of your feet on the floor.
Place your forearms on the floor, with your elbows directly under your shoulders and your forearms parallel to the floor. Spread your hands, with your palms down and your fingers pointing forward.
On an inhale, use the strength of your back muscles to lift your chest and head off the floor, keeping your spine long. Press your tailbone down and tuck your pubic bone in, keeping your lower back stable.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your shoulders and abdomen a bit more. Hold for 5-10 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your spine.
On an exhale, slowly lower your chest and head, and return to a face-down position.

name: Monkey Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Thighs, Hamstrings, and Groin: Effectively improves leg flexibility and range of motion.
Stimulates Abdominal Organs: Promotes digestion and relieves constipation.
Strengthens the Core: Maintaining hip alignment and balance requires core engagement.
Relieves Sciatica: The stretching of leg muscles reduces pressure on the sciatic nerve.
Enhances Courage and Focus: Practicing Hanumanasana requires patience and focus, which helps cultivate inner courage.
description:
Start in a low lunge, with your right leg forward and your left leg back, your left knee gently on the mat, and the top of your foot on the floor.
Slowly slide your right leg forward, straightening your knee, and ensuring your hips remain facing forward. Push your right heel forward to lengthen your hamstring, with your toes pointing toward the ceiling.
Gradually slide your left knee backward until your shin and knee touch the floor, with the top of your left foot flat. Actively lengthen the front of your left thigh and your hip flexor, keeping your leg engaged.
Ensure both of your hips are at the same level, avoiding one hip lifting. Pull your front hip back and push your back hip forward to keep your hips centered.
Once your hips are stable, raise your hands from your hips over your head in Anjali Mudra (Prayer Pose), lengthening your spine. Relax your shoulders, avoiding shrugging, and keep space in your neck.
Hold the pose with deep breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 5-10 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your legs.
Slowly slide your right leg back, return to a low lunge, and then repeat on the other side.

name: Standing Splits Pose
benefits:
Stretches the Hamstrings, Calves, and Thighs: Effectively relieves leg tension and stiffness.
Strengthens the Legs, Knees, and Ankles.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
Improves Posture: The stretching of the back and shoulders helps relieve stiffness from prolonged sitting.
description:
Start in Standing Forward Bend, with your feet together and your hands on the floor at your sides, keeping your spine long.
On an inhale, look forward, finding a focal point on the floor in front of you to help maintain balance. Slowly move your hands forward, shifting your body weight forward.
Transfer your body weight to one foot (e.g., your right foot), keeping your right leg straight and your heel firmly rooted to the floor. Slowly lift your left leg backward and upward, lifting it as high as you can, keeping your left leg straight.
Keep your left hip aligned with your right hip, with your left hip bone pointing downward and your left toes rotating inward, toward the midline of your body. If needed, you can slightly bend your right knee to maintain body stability.
Keep your chest close to your right thigh, feeling the lengthening of your spine and the stretch in your legs. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength in your legs.
Slowly lower your left leg, return to Standing Forward Bend. Repeat on the other side.

name: Center Splits Pose
benefits:
Enhances Flexibility in the Hips, Groin, Legs, Ankles, and Back.
Strengthens the Thighs, Calves, and Upper Body.
Relieves Shoulder Stiffness.
Enhances Balance.
Stretches the Spine and Strengthens Supporting Muscles.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat with your legs straight in front of you and your back straight.
On an inhale, place your hands at your sides, relaxing your shoulders. On an exhale, slowly open your legs to the sides, going as wide as you can, but don't force it.
Place your hands at your sides, with your palms down, your fingers spread, and pressing into the floor. Keep your spine long, avoiding arching your lower back, and let your head hang naturally.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your legs.
Slowly bring your legs back together, return to the starting position, and relax your entire body.

name: Staff Pose
benefits:
Strengthens the Back and Core: Staff Pose requires a straight spine and a gentle engagement of the abdomen, which strengthens the back and core muscles.
Lengthens the Leg Muscles: The pose requires keeping the legs straight and engaged, which effectively stretches the leg muscles (especially the hamstrings and calves).
Improves Posture: Cultivates awareness of spinal alignment, which can improve daily sitting posture and reduce back and waist pressure.
description:
Start by sitting on your mat, with your legs straight out in front of you, your toes pointing toward the ceiling, and your heels gently pushing forward. Keep your legs together, ensuring your knees and ankles are not turned outward or inward.
Root your sit bones firmly into the mat, feeling them support your entire body weight. On an inhale, imagine your spine lengthening from your sit bones to the crown of your head, keeping your back straight.
Relax your shoulders naturally, avoiding shrugging. Gently squeeze your shoulder blades down, keeping your chest open.
Place your hands on the floor at your sides, with your fingertips pointing forward and your palms gently pressing into the floor. You can use a little force with your arms to help keep your back straight.
Keep your legs straight and engaged, with your toes pointing up and your heels pushing forward. Gently tighten your thigh muscles, feeling the lengthening and stretching of your legs.
Hold the pose with deep, steady breaths. With each inhale, feel your spine lengthen; with each exhale, relax your shoulders and facial tension. You can hold Staff Pose for 5 to 10 breaths, feeling your body's alignment and stability.
To exit the pose, keep your spine long and gently relax your hands and legs. If your lower back feels tense, you can slightly bend your knees to relax your back.

name: Inverted Staff
benefits:
Stretches the Entire Front of the Body: Including the chest, abdomen, and front of the thighs.
Opens the Chest: Improves respiratory efficiency and increases lung capacity.
Enhances Spinal Flexibility: The backbend increases spinal flexibility.
Stimulates Internal Organs: Gently massages the heart, enhancing heart function and preventing arterial embolism.
Boosts Nervous System Vitality: The backbend stimulates the adrenal glands, thyroid, pituitary gland, and pineal gland.
description:
Start in the preparation for Wheel Pose, with your hands placed on the floor on either side of your head, and your elbows shoulder-width apart.
On an inhale, place your elbows on the floor and interlace your fingers around your head, similar to Headstand.
Press your forearms into the floor and gently lift your head off the floor. Slowly straighten your legs backward, bringing your heels together and flexing your toes to engage your leg muscles.
Keep your spine long and your chest open, feeling the stretch in the entire front of your body. Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 5-10 breaths.
Slowly lower your head, return to the preparation for Wheel Pose.

name: Standing Foot Behind the Head
benefits:
Strengthens the Core and Arms: Supports body weight, building strength in the core and arms.
Stretches the Spine, Hips, and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves tension in the back and legs.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
description:
Start in Tadasana (Mountain Pose), with your feet together and your hands at your sides.
Slowly lift your right leg and place your right foot on the inside of your left thigh, as close to your left groin as possible, forming Half Lotus Pose.
Use your core strength to wrap your right leg behind your head, placing your right foot behind your head, with the top of your right foot tight against your head.
Place your hands in Anjali Mudra (Prayer Pose) in front of your chest. Keep your spine long, avoiding arching your lower back.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your legs.
Slowly lower your right leg and return to Tadasana. Repeat on the other side.

name: Standing Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend
benefits:
Stretches the Hips, Hamstrings, Shoulders, and Knees: Effectively relieves tension in these areas.
Strengthens the Legs and Core: Standing on one leg improves leg and core stability.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
description:
Start in Half Lotus Standing Pose, with your right foot on your left thigh, forming Half Lotus Pose. Stand on your left leg, maintaining balance.
On an inhale, extend your left arm upward, perpendicular to the floor. Grab your right foot with your right hand, maintaining the bind of the Half Lotus.
Fold your body forward from your hip joints, extending your left arm forward, and then slowly moving it down until your hand can touch the floor. Maintain the bind on your right foot, trying to bring your forehead close to your left shin.
Place your left hand on the floor outside your left foot. Keep your spine long, avoiding arching your lower back. Bring your chin closer to your chest, feeling the relaxation in your neck.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch in your hips and legs.
Slowly lift your body, return to Half Lotus Standing Pose. Repeat on the other side.

name: Standing Hand to Big Toe
benefits:
Stretches the Hamstrings: Effectively relieves leg tension and stiffness.
Strengthens the Legs: Supports body weight, strengthening the leg muscles.
Enhances Balance: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
Relieves Stress: Deep stretching helps calm the mind.
description:
Start in Tadasana (Mountain Pose), with your feet together and your hands at your sides.
Shift your body weight to your left foot, rooting it firmly into the floor. Bend your right knee and lift it toward your chest.
Grab your right big toe with your right index and middle fingers, wrapping your right arm inward around your right leg.
Slowly straighten your right leg forward, keeping your right knee straight and feeling the stretch in your hamstring. Place your left hand on your left hip, maintaining body balance, and ensuring your hips are facing forward.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your legs and back a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the stretch and strength of your legs.
Slowly lower your body, bring your right leg back, and return to Tadasana. Repeat on the other side.

name: Extended Standing Hand to Big Toe
benefits:
Stretches the Hips and Hamstrings: Effectively relieves leg tension and stiffness.
Strengthens the Ankle, Knee, Hip, and Shoulder Joints.
Strengthens the Core: Engaging the abdominal core to maintain balance.
Enhances Balance and Focus: Requires a high degree of focus and balance.
Calms the Mind: Deep stretching helps relieve stress and anxiety.
description:
Start in Tadasana (Mountain Pose), with your feet together and your hands at your sides.
On an exhale, lift your right knee toward your chest.
Grab your right big toe with your right thumb, index finger, and middle finger.
Balance on your left leg. On an inhale, extend your right foot forward and to the right side. Keep your right leg straight, feeling the stretch in your hip and hamstring.
Hold the pose with steady breaths. With each inhale, lengthen your spine, and with each exhale, relax your body a bit more. Hold for 3-5 breaths, feeling the balance and strength of your body.
On an exhale, slowly lower your right foot and return to Tadasana. Repeat on the other side.
